texts.definition: Points that players use to be able to do actions.
markups: <style="Definition">Points that players use to be able to do actions.</style>

Games that wish to make players have to husband the actions they perform can use <style="CurrentLink">Budgeted Action Points</style>. This gives players a limited amount of points that can be used to pay for the actions they wish to perform. Usually they not only let players have a set of actions to choose from but also allow them to perform the same actions several times if they wished to.

A form of <style="CurrentLink">Budgeted Action Points</style> is used to control how often certain actions can be performed in real-time games. In this case the actions costs a certain amount of points from some value and this value slowly increases until it has reached a maximum point. This means that the amount of uses of the action during a certain amount of time is limited but players can save up points in order to use the actions several times quickly after one another.
Note: BoardGameGeek uses Action Point Allowance System to describe a similar concept.

The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Board%20Games">Board Game</link></style> <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Space%20Hulk">Space Hulk</link></style> has a limited set of action points for each unit in the game. For the player controlling genestealers these action points are used for moving, turning, and attacking in close combat while the player controlling the space marines can use them for these activities and additionally to shoot and reload weapons. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Conflict%20of%20Heroes:%20Awakening%20the%20Bear!%20Russia%201941-1942">Conflict of Heroes: Awakening the Bear! Russia 1941-1942</link></style> has a similar structure but players only activate one unit before the turn passes to the other player. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Cartagena">Cartagena</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Forbidden%20Island">Forbidden Island</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Pandemic">Pandemic</link></style> also make use of <style="CurrentLink">Budgeted Action Points</style> but for less violent activities. <style="CurrentLink">Budgeted Action Points</style> can also be used for more abstract actions in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Board%20Games">Board Game</link></style>: <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ticket%20to%20Ride">Ticket to Ride</link></style> uses it to let players take new cards or place railway lines while <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Neuroshima%20Hex">Neuroshima Hex</link></style> uses it to let players choose two out of three chips that either place units or activate events. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Agricola">Agricola</link></style> lets players have as many actions as they have members in their families but players alternate using their actions until all have been used. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dominant%20Species">Dominant Species</link></style> provide players with various amounts of tokens to use each turn depending on how many players are playing the game, but players can gain or lose such tokens during gameplay (in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Agricola">Agricola</link></style> players can also gain but not lose family members).

Budgeted Action Points are also used in some Computer Games. The early installments of the Fallout series uses it in combat while Fallout 3 and Fallout: New Vegas has it as an optional mode in combat (called V.A.T.S). Calling air strikes, producing ammunition boxes, or handing out health packs in Return to Castle Wolfenstein: Enemy Territory all requires resources. These resources are limited but are regained over time, letting players choose between continuously doing the actions at regular intervals or saving up to do several of them in a short time span. The Europa Universalis series have several different types of Budgeted Action Points represented as diplomats, magisters, missionaries, etc. that each can be used for various actions in the games. CityVille, Empires & Allies, and Ravenwood Fair also use a similar system, having a maximum amount of points one can store and replenishing one point every five minutes.

Three main aspects need to be considered when creating games with <style="CurrentLink">Budgeted Action Points</style>: what actions are controlled by this system, how much points do players have access to, and how are the points replenished?

The selection of possible actions which can be paid by the <style="CurrentLink">Budgeted Action Points</style> can be any kind of action that is part of the overall game play. However, the action points may be for all actions, or individual budgets may exist for each <style="Link"><link="characters">Character</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="units">Unit</link></style>. The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Europa%20Universalis%20series">Europa Universalis series</link></style> shows how different budgets can be created for various abstract actions also. For <style="CurrentLink">Budgeted Action Points</style> that are used during gameplay for <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, one common set of possible actions include <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style> and different forms of actions related to <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style>. One possible variation is to make it possible or not to reuse the same actions several times. Another, more abstract and strategic, set of possible actions include doing <style="Link"><link="investments">Investments</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Technology%20Trees">Technology Trees</link></style> or choosing which <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Producers">Producers</link></style> to activate. <style="CurrentLink">Budgeted Action Points</style> can also be used to drive <style="Link"><link="token-placement">Token Placement</link></style> systems where players use their action points to select which actions are to be done later, and this  typically divides gameplay into <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Planning%20Phases">Planning Phases</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Execution%20Phases">Execution Phases</link></style>. All these actions may be constructed so they are performed at once or put in a sequence through <style="Link"><link="action-programming">Action Programming</link></style> that will be evaluated later. <style="CurrentLink">Budgeted Action Points</style> can also be used before gameplay, this is most often used to give players ways to select <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Attributes">Attributes</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="equipment">Equipment</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="skills">Skills</link></style>, as well as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Advantages">Advantages</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Disadvantages">Disadvantages</link></style> for <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>.

The amount of points available are mostly affected by how much of a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Resources">Limited Resource</link></style> they should be, the risk of causing <style="Link"><link="analysis-paralysis">Analysis Paralysis</link></style> and having the right level of <style="Link"><link="predictable-consequences">Predictable Consequences</link></style> for other players. However, related to this is the cost of the actions. By having different costs for different actions, <style="Link"><link="balancing-effects">Balancing Effects</link></style> can be put in place but also differences in <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style> through <style="Link"><link="environmental-effects">Environmental Effects</link></style>. Having different costs also changes how often different actions are used (heavily affected by how many points are available) but balancing the selection of actions can also be accomplished by introducing <style="Link"><link="no-use-bonus">No-Use Bonuses</link></style> (e.g. the resource producing tiles in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Agricola">Agricola</link></style>).

How <style="CurrentLink">Budgeted Action Points</style> can be replenished depend primarily on how game time is updated. In games with <style="Link"><link="turn-taking">Turn Taking</link></style> or other <style="Link"><link="turn-based-games">Turn-Based Games</link></style>, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Space%20Hulk">Space Hulk</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Cartagena">Cartagena</link></style>, this is typically done through refilling the whole supply of action points every turn, but <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Agricola">Agricola</link></style> shows an alternative by letting players spend one action on their turn and then moving on to the next players until all action points have been spend and only then replenishing everybody's supply. In <style="Link"><link="real-time-games">Real-Time</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="tick-based-games">Tick-Based Games</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Budgeted Action Points</style> are typically <style="Link"><link="renewable-resources">Renewable Resources</link></style> through <style="Link"><link="regenerating-resources">Regenerating</link></style> over time. The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Return%20to%20Castle%20Wolfenstein:%20Enemy%20Territory">Return to Castle Wolfenstein: Enemy Territory</link></style> and the computer-version of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Space%20Hulk%20(video%20game)">Space Hulk</link></style> are examples of these design solutions. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/CityVille">CityVille</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ravenwood%20Fair">Ravenwood Fair</link></style> work similarly but also offer action points as <style="Link"><link="purchasable-game-advantages">Purchasable Game Advantages</link></style> - this does not disturb <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player Balance</link></style> since these are <style="Link"><link="massively-single-player-online-games">Massively Single-Player Online Games</link></style>.

<style="Link"><link="cards">Cards</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Chips">Chips</link></style> can be used when <style="CurrentLink">Budgeted Action Points</style> need to be represented by game elements. <style="Link"><link="game-state-indicators">Game State Indicators</link></style> can be used in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Computer%20Games">Computer Games</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Budgeted Action Points</style> gives players a <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> of which actions within a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Set%20of%20Actions">Limited Set of Actions</link></style> they wish to do, and they also provide <style="Link"><link="action-caps">Action Caps</link></style> since only a limited number of actions can be done within a time limit. They are indirect <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> which inherently are <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Resources">Limited Resources</link></style> since they have <style="Link"><link="resource-caps">Resource Caps</link></style>, and when controlling <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style> they also impose <style="Link"><link="movement-limitations">Movement Limitations</link></style>. Handling these requires <style="Link"><link="resource-management">Resource Management</link></style> and often also considering <style="Link"><link="trade-offs">Trade-Offs</link></style> between the different possible actions available, both which help create more <style="Link"><link="complex-gameplay">Complex Gameplay</link></style>.

The <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> that <style="CurrentLink">Budgeted Action Points</style> gives <style="Link"><link="stimulated-planning">Stimulated Planning</link></style> regarding <style="Link"><link="tactical-planning">Tactical Planning</link></style>, and through this possibly also <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Cognitive%20Engrossment">Cognitive Engrossment</link></style>. However, in games that are <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="turn-based-games">Turn-Based</link></style>, this can cause <style="Link"><link="analysis-paralysis">Analysis Paralysis</link></style>. For games with <style="Link"><link="persistent-game-worlds">Persistent Game Worlds</link></style> and where the <style="CurrentLink">Budgeted Action Points</style> are <style="Link"><link="regenerating-resources">Regenerating Resources</link></style>, this combination supports <style="Link"><link="encouraged-return-visits">Encouraged Return Visits</link></style>. Similarly, the combination of <style="CurrentLink">Budgeted Action Points</style> and <style="Link"><link="regenerating-resources">Regenerating Resources</link></style> can be used to create <style="Link"><link="tick-based-games">Tick-Based Games</link></style>. In any type of game running out of <style="CurrentLink">Budgeted Action Points</style> can lead to <style="Link"><link="helplessness">Helplessness</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Budgeted Action Points</style> can have <style="Link"><link="balancing-effects">Balancing Effects</link></style> on powerful abilities since these may cost more points and not be usable so often. Further, the impact of <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New Abilities</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style> is lessened when used together with <style="CurrentLink">Budgeted Action Points</style> as using them requires players to not use other actions.
